content:
Thought I'd share my solution here too (Ruby):
h={}
a=0,0
$<.map{eval"I,T,C="+_1.split*?,
V||=I
!T||V+(h[I]||-V)>C||(h[I]=C;a[T]+=1)}
$><<a*' '

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool subject and understandable. I like the fact that you can follow the story to find the logic directly.  Like this one :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this kind of CoC puzzles: the description tells a story and the solution is not a one-liner.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, perfect difficulty for a CoC, tested in Java. Posting simple Java solution in reply to this comment.

Rewrote the first paragraph of the statement:

"You have set up a voting system between two candidates 0 and 1. It's an online one and at the moment it has the drawback of allowing unlimited votes per user. To prevent abuses, you decide to not take into account the votes of the same user if they were cast in less than timeout seconds of his/her last valid vote. When timeout seconds have elapsed from his/her last valid vote, you allow them to vote again (so they are incentivized to go back and watch the ruthless ads that you have on your site)."

To

"You've established an online voting system for two candidates, labeled as 0 and 1. Currently, this system lacks restrictions and permits users to cast an unlimited number of votes. To counter potential misuse, you've opted to disregard additional votes from the same user if they were submitted within a timeframe of timeout seconds since their last valid vote. After the passage of timeout seconds from their last valid vote, users are eligible to vote once more."
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
Really great, interesting for beginners to test easy conditions and challenging for medium skilled devs with size of code and speed constrainst
Can't wait to solve ur contribution in the upcoming CoC

Changes:

- Reordered [candidate / time / id] to [id / candidate / time] (statement, tests and stub variable names) (@iwalse, @Janiks)
- Fixed some typos (@Janiks)
- Added 0 < n_entries <= 100 in constraints
- Rewording of the input section
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Small typo: "ruthless adds" should be "ruthless ads". Also, I feel like the final sentence would read better as: "Find the results for the two candidates and print them on the same line."

Other than that, the description is easy to understand. I would just reorder the inputs, as suggested by iwalse.

Funny idea! Not sure if it's only me but I think it will be quicker to understand it if we have the three space-separated integers in this order:
1) user_id
2) vote
3) time
To have something like a sentence: subject what (/verb) when (/complement).

In the same goal to understand it quicker, can we repeat "The vote goes to x" in the example?

Here what the example will look like if you agree:
0 0 1   <- First vote of user 0, ok. 			         The vote goes to 1.
0 1 15 <- Less than 30 s have elapsed, ignored.
1 1 15 <- First vote by user 1, ok. 			         The vote goes to 1.
2 1 15 <- First vote by user 2, ok. 			         The vote goes to 1.
0 1 30 <- At least 30 s since last vote of user 0, ok. The vote goes to 0.
0 1 35 <- Less than 30 s have elapsed, ignored.
0 1 50 <- At least 30 s since last vote of user 1, ok. The vote goes to 0.

What do you think?

Goal section
* Please change "person" to "user" (I was confused initially because I thought "person" meant "candidate").

Input section
* Note 2: Suggest to mention "starting from {{0}} and incrementing by {{1}} for each new user".

Constraints section
* [[time]] may be 0, so please correct the third constraint.

Stub generator
* Suggest to change line 3 so that the initial stub provides 3 integers instead of a string.

If this is changed, "a space separated string containing three integers" may be simplified as "three space-separated integers" as well.

Thanks.
Thanks! I think I fixed everything.

I've reordered the inputs but I'm afraid I can't do what you ask for the example because long lines in monospace are hard to see in the IDE (they don't fit the width and it's a pain to read during the clash).

Plus the first line, which has "the vote goes to X" should be enough anyway. There is no ambiguity possible.

Suggest to change "once more" to "again" to avoid any unintended misinterpretation that voters can vote only one more time and no more (although it's been mentioned that the number of votes is unlimited).

Here's my short (might be shorter I guess) python solution:

T,_,*V=open(0)
T=int(T)
w={}
W=[0,0]
for i in V:
    u,v,t=map(int,i.split())
    if t-w.get(u,-T)>=T:
        W[v]=W[v]+1
        w[u]=t
print(*W)
Done, thanks.
Ok, no problem. Sorry I didn't know about that. Thank you!

Input section
* Please change "users [[id]]s" to "[[user_id]]s" for consistency.

Output section
* Please add "separated with a space".

Thanks.
Fixed, thanks!
